Description: Lid sherd of Chian black figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl with trace of handle root; white slip; interior: reserved; exterior: from top by handle root, part of tongue pattern in outline; at right, maeander pattern; below, tongue pattern in between concentric brown bands; below, black figure decoration consisting of sirens (from left, body and tail feathers of first siren with trace of added red on wing and followed by second siren), both to left; incised pendant, rising and full rosettes with red centres as filling ornament; below, trace of brown band.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Boardman notes that the sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G120.8 and AN1896-1908-G120.20. The creatures on AN1896-1908-G120.8 are more likely to represent sphinxes since the figure on the far left has a tail and the figure on the right has a curlicue which is also seen on sirens in general but not on the siren depicted on this sherd. Lemos places this sherd in Stage 1 of Group D of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Although the imagery is lively, the execution of the figures is loose and careless.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 314, no. 1343, pl. 174 (top middle))
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2135) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
